'''WorldWinner''' is a cross-platform, skill-based games community that operates competitive cash tournaments for web, mobile web, and mobile ([[iOS]]) platforms. Games include Solitaire Rush, Wheel of Fortune®, SCRABBLE Cubes, and Tetris® Burst. In 2018, WorldWinner launched Angry Birds Champions, the official cash tournament version of [[Rovio Entertainment]]'s Angry Birds.
WorldWinner is based in Boston, MA and operates under the [[Game Show Network]]’s GSN Games division.
== History == Worldwinner was founded in 1999 in Newton, Massachusetts<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/WorldWinner.com+Launches+Online+Gaming+Site+that+Rewards+Skilled...-a064329455|title=WorldWinner.com Launches Online Gaming Site that Rewards Skilled Players with Cash Prizes; New Gaming Destination Brings the Thrill of Competition to Familiar Games. - Free Online Library|website=www.thefreelibrary.com|access-date=2018-01-22}}</ref> by Alex Bloom (formerly Saidakovsky), Alex Ganelis, and Daniil Utin, raising over $17 million from leading venture capital firms, including HarbourVest Partners and Benchmark Capital.
WorldWinner launched on August 17, 2000 as the first online gaming destination allowing participants to compete in skill-based tournaments for real-money winnings. The company established partnerships with leading casual games sites, including Yahoo!, EA, Pogo, iWon, PAX TV, WildTangent, and Shockwave. By 2002, WorldWinner was hosting more than two million tournaments per month, with more than $100,000 in daily cash winnings.
From 2000 to 2004, WorldWinner reported a revenue increase of 2,386 percent, earning the number six spot on the Technology Fast 50 for New England.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/worldwinner-ranks-sixth-on-deloittes-technology-fast-50-list-55240512.html|title=WorldWinner Ranks Sixth on Deloitte's Technology Fast 50 List|last=Inc.|first=WorldWinner,|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-22}}</ref> During that time, Saidakovsky, Ganelis, and Utin obtained a patent for their tournament technology.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pimg-faiw.uspto.gov/fdd/79/2002/53/005/0.pdf|title=Minimizing the effects of chance, US Patent|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> By 2004, WorldWinner had over 14 million registered players worldwide, hosting more than four million tournaments and awarding millions of dollars in prizes every month.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/worldwinner-explodes-in-2004-with-record-revenues-54063537.html|title=WorldWinner Explodes in 2004 with Record Revenues|last=Inc.|first=WorldWinner,|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-22}}</ref>
In March 2006, WorldWinner was acquired by [[FUN Technologies]] and merged with SkillJam into WorldWinner, dropping the SkillJam brand.
In December 2007, [[Liberty Media]] acquired FUN Technologies<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ir.libertymedia.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=576103|title=Liberty Media Corporation Completes Acquisition of FUN Technologies Inc.|access-date=2018-01-22|language=en}}</ref> in a transaction valuing the company at $484 million. As a result of the acquisition, WorldWinner integrated with the Liberty-owned Game Show Network, and FUN Technologies was discontinued as a brand. WorldWinner rebranded to GSN Cash Games in 2013. The company also launched its mobile web offering (GSN Cash Games Mobile) in 2014, allowing players to compete in cash tournaments on mobile devices.
In 2017, GSN Cash Games re-branded back to WorldWinner, simultaneously launching a cash tournament version of Solitaire TriPeaks, based on the Solitaire TriPeaks app by GSN Games.
In July 2017, WorldWinner launched its iOS app, followed by Android in May 2018.
As of June 2018, WorldWinner is no longer available in the [[European Union|EU]].
== Cash tournament model == WorldWinner hosts different types of cash tournaments with varying player pools, prize pools, entry fees, and difficulty level. Players are matched with other players of similar skill. Unlike gambling games that, from a legal standpoint, feature the elements of chance, prize, and consideration, WorldWinner games are modified so that player skill (as opposed to chance or luck) is the predominant factor in performance and winnings.
WorldWinner also offers free Warm-Up tournaments.
== Games == WorldWinner’s portfolio includes online and mobile games based on popular [[card game]]s, [[Puzzle Game|puzzle games]], [[word game]]s, [[board game]]s, [[Game show|TV game show games]], arcade games, and match-three games. {| class="wikitable" |'''Game''' |'''Availability''' |- |Angry Birds Champions |App, web |- |Wheel of Fortune® |App, web, mobile web |- |SCRABBLE Cubes |App, web, mobile web |- |Tetris® Burst |App, web |- |Solitaire Rush |App, web, mobile web |- |PAC-MAN™ |App |- |TRIVIAL PURSUIT |App, web |- |Solitaire TriPeaks |App, web |- |Catch 21® |App, web, mobile web |- |Big Money™ |Web, mobile web |- |The Price Is Right®: Super Plinko™ |Web, mobile web |- |Bejeweled® 2 |Web |- |Bejeweled® Blitz: Rubies and Riches |Web |- |Cubis |Web |- |Dynomite!™ |Web |- |Luxor |Web |- |Mahjongg Dimensions |Web |- |Pyramid Solitaire Adventures |Web |- |SCRABBLE BOGGLE |Web |- |Spades |Web |- |Spider Solitaire |Web |- |SwapIt! |Web |- |SwapIt 2 |App, web, mobile web |- |Swipe Hype |Web |- |Word Mojo |Web |- |Vegas Nights 2 |Web |- |Zen Gems |Web |}
== Charitable donations == WorldWinner and GSN Games have collectively supported many nonprofit groups, donating a portion of tournament entry fees to organizations such as Toys for Tots, the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), and the Pediatric Brain Tumor Foundation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gamezone.com/news/worldwinner_kicks_off_charitable_online_games_competitions_during_national_breast_cancer_awareness_month/|title=WorldWinner Kicks off Charitable Online Games Competitions during National Breast Cancer Awareness Month - GameZone|date=2012-05-04|work=GameZone|access-date=2018-01-22|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/mass-high-tech/2005/05/worldwinner-launches-compete-for-pink.html|title=WorldWinner launches "Compete for Pink" for breast cancer funds|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-22}}</ref>

{{short description|Leopard population in Zanzibar}} {{subspeciesbox | name = Zanzibar leopard | image = Zanzibar Leopard 2.JPG | image_caption = Mounted specimen in the Zanzibar Museum <!-- | status of SUBspecies is not assessed in IUCN Red List |status_system = |status_ref = --> | genus = Panthera | species = pardus | species_link = Leopard | subspecies = pardus | authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|1758]]) | synonyms = formerly ''P. p. adersi''<ref name="Pocock1932"/> }}
The '''Zanzibar leopard''' is an [[African leopard]] (''Panthera pardus pardus'') population on [[Unguja|Unguja Island]] in the [[Zanzibar]] archipelago, [[Tanzania]]. It is the island's largest terrestrial [[carnivore]] and [[apex predator]]. In 2008, it was considered [[extinct]] due to persecution by local hunters.<ref name=WalshGoldman08>{{cite journal |author1=Walsh, M.T. |author2=Goldman, H.V. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2008 |title=Updating the Inventory of Zanzibar Leopard Specimens |url=https://www.academia.edu/694088/Updating_the_inventory_of_Zanzibar_leopard_specimens/ |journal=Cat News |volume=49 |pages=4–6}}</ref> Increasing conflict between people and leopards in the 20th century led to their demonization and determined attempts to exterminate them. Efforts to develop a leopard [[conservation biology|conservation]] program in the mid-1990s were shelved when wildlife researchers concluded that there was little prospect for the population's long-term survival.<ref name=Stuart/> However, camera trap footage revealed in 2018 of a similar-looking leopard has renewed hopes for the population's survival, though little information is known.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.insideedition.com/zanzibar-leopard-captured-camera-despite-being-declared-extinct-43962|title=Zanzibar Leopard Captured on Camera, Despite Being Declared Extinct|work=Inside Edition|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en}}</ref>
The Zanzibar leopard was described as a [[leopard]] [[subspecies]] by [[Reginald Innes Pocock]], who proposed the [[scientific name]] ''Panthera pardus adersi'' in 1932.<ref name="Pocock1932">{{cite journal |last1=Pocock|first1=R. I. |date=1932 |title=The Leopards of Africa |url=|journal=Proceedings of the Zoological Society of London|volume=102|issue=2|pages=543–591|doi=10.1111/j.1096-3642.1932.tb01085.x|via=}}</ref> In 1996, it was subsumed to ''P. p. pardus''.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Miththapala |first=S. |author2=Seidensticker, J. |author3=O'Brien, S. J. |year=1996 |title=Phylogeographic Subspecies Recognition in Leopards (''P. pardus''): Molecular Genetic Variation |journal=Conservation Biology |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=1115–1132 | doi=10.1046/j.1523-1739.1996.10041115.x }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Uphyrkina|first=O. |last2=Johnson |first2=E.W. |last3=Quigley |first3=H. |last4=Miquelle |first4=D. |last5=Marker |first5=L. |last6=Bush |first6=M. |last7=O'Brien |first7=S. J. |year=2001 |title=Phylogenetics, genome diversity and origin of modern leopard, ''Panthera pardus'' |journal=Molecular Ecology |volume=10 |issue=11 |pages=2617–2633 |url=http://www.biosoil.ru/files/00001386.pdf |doi=10.1046/j.0962-1083.2001.01350.x|pmid=11883877}}</ref>
== Evolutionary history == The [[evolution]]ary history of the Zanzibar leopard parallels that of other endemics on Unguja, including the [[Zanzibar servaline genet]] and the [[Zanzibar red colobus]]. It is thought to have evolved in isolation from the African leopard since at least the end of the [[Last glacial period|Ice Age]], when the island was separated from mainland Tanzania by rising [[sea level]]s. The [[founder effect]] and [[adaptation]] to local conditions produced a smaller leopard than its continental relatives and one whose [[rosette (zoology)|rosettes]] have partially disintegrated into spots.<ref name=Pakenham1984>{{cite book | author = Pakenham, R.H.W. | year = 1984 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/14538645/The-Mammals-of-Zanzibar-and-Pemba/ | title = The Mammals of Zanzibar and Pemba Islands | location = Harpenden | publisher = privately printed}}</ref><ref name=Kingdon1989>{{cite book | author = Kingdon, J. | year = 1989 | title = Island Africa: The Evolution of Africa's Rare Animals and Plants | location = Princeton | publisher = [[Princeton University Press]]}}</ref>
== Behavior and Ecology == Very little is known about the Zanzibar leopard's [[behavior]] and ecology.<ref name=Walsh>{{cite journal |author1=Walsh, M.T. |author2=Goldman, H.V. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2003 |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/14568104/The-Zanzibar-Leopard-between-Science-and-Cryptozoology/ |title=The Zanzibar Leopard Between Science and Cryptozoology |journal=Nature East Africa |volume=33 |issue=1/2 |pages=14–16}}</ref> It has never been studied in the wild, and the last sighting of a live leopard happened in the early 1980s.<ref name=Swai1983>Swai, I.S. (1983). ''Wildlife Conservation Status in Zanzibar''. Unpublished M.Sc. dissertation, [[University of Dar es Salaam]].</ref> Most [[zoology|zoologists]] have since presumed the Zanzibar leopard to be extinct or very nearly so.<ref name=Stuart>{{cite book |authors=Stuart, C. & Stuart, T. |year=1997 |title=A Preliminary Faunal Survey of South-eastern Unguja (Zanzibar) with Special Emphasis on the Leopard ''Panthera pardus adersi'' |publisher=African-Arabian Wildlife Research Centre |location=Loxton, South Africa}}</ref>
Only six skins have been located in museums, including the [[type (zoology)|type specimen]] in the [[Natural History Museum, London]], and a much-faded mounted specimen in the [[Zanzibar Museum]].<ref name=WalshGoldman08/> However, Zanzibar government statistics indicate that leopards were still being killed by hunters in the mid-1990s, and islanders continue to report sightings and [[livestock]] [[predation]].<ref name=Goldman2002>{{cite journal |author1=Goldman, H.V. |author2=Walsh, M.T. |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 2002 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/13994714/Is-the-Zanzibar-Leopard-Panthera-pardus-adersi-Extinct/ | title = Is the Zanzibar Leopard (''Panthera pardus adersi'') Extinct? | journal = Journal of East African Natural History | volume = 91 | issue = 1/2 | pages = 15–25 | doi = 10.2982/0012-8317(2002)91[15:ITZLPP]2.0.CO;2 | issn = 0012-8317}}</ref>
== Extirpation == [[File:Zanzibar Leopard 8.JPG|thumb|Close up of head]] Rural Zanzibaris’ descriptions of the leopard and its habits are characterized by the widespread [[belief]] that a large number of these [[carnivore]]s are kept by [[witchcraft|witches]] and sent by them to harm or otherwise harass villagers. This belief comes together with an elaborate package of ideas about how leopards are bred, trained, exchanged and sent to do the evil bidding of their owners. For local farmers this supplies a neat explanation for [[predation]] by leopards, and more generally for their appearance "out of place" in the vicinity of farms and villages.<ref name=Goldman1997>{{cite web |author1=Goldman, H.V. |author2=Walsh, M.T. |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 1997 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/17317225/A-Leopard-in-Jeopardy-An-Anthropological-Survey-of-Practices-and-Beliefs-which-Threaten-the-Survival-of-the-Zanzibar-Leopard-Panthera-pardus-adersi/ | title = A Leopard in Jeopardy: An Anthropological Survey of Practices and Beliefs which Threaten the Survival of the Zanzibar Leopard (''Panthera pardus adersi'') | work = Zanzibar Forestry Technical Paper No. 63, Jozani-Chwaka Bay Conservation Project, Commission for Natural Resources, Zanzibar | accessdate = 2011-05-29}}</ref>
The growth of human [[population]] and [[agriculture]] in the 20th century was largely responsible for this state of affairs, as people encroached on leopard [[habitat (ecology)|habitat]] and prey species. Increasing conflict with leopards and the fear that this generated led to a series of campaigns to exterminate them. These were localized at first, but became island-wide after the [[Zanzibar Revolution]] of 1964, when a combined anti-[[witchcraft]] and leopard-killing campaign was launched under the leadership of a witch-finder.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Walsh| first1=M.T.|last2=Goldman| first2=H.V.|editor1-first=E.| editor1-last=Dounias |editor2-first=E.| editor2-last=Motte-Florac |editor3-first=M.| editor3-last=Dunham|title=Le symbolisme des animaux: L'animal, clef de voûte de la relation entre l'homme et la nature? [Animal symbolism: Animals, keystone of the relationship between man and nature?] |publisher=Éditions de l’IRD |location = Paris|date=2007 |pages=1133–1182 |chapter=Killing the King: The Demonization and Extermination of the Zanzibar Leopard [Tuer le roi: la diabolisation et l’extermination du leopard de Zanzibar] |chapterurl=https://www.scribd.com/doc/14070237/Killing-the-King-The-Demonization-and-Extermination-of-the-Zanzibar-Leopard/ }}</ref> The long-term result of this campaign and the subsequent classification of the leopard as "[[vermin]]" was to bring them to the brink of [[extinction]].<ref name=Walsh/>
== Conservation== Serious attention was not paid to the Zanzibar leopard's plight until the mid-1990s, by which time some authorities were already listing it as extinct.<ref name=Nowell>{{cite book |author1=Nowell, K. |author2=Jackson, P. |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 1996 | url = http://www.carnivoreconservation.org/files/actionplans/wildcats.pdf/ | title = Wild Cats: Status Survey and Conservation Action Plan | location = Gland, Switzerland | publisher = [[IUCN]]}}</ref> A leopard conservation program was drafted by the [[CARE (relief)|CARE]]-funded Jozani-Chwaka Bay Conservation Project, but abandoned in 1997 when wildlife researchers failed to find evidence for the leopard's continuing presence in and around [[Jozani forest]].<ref name=Stuart/>
Local wildlife officials, however, remained more optimistic about the leopard's survival, and some Zanzibaris have proposed approaching alleged leopard keepers in order to ask them to display their leopards to paying visitors. Villagers sometimes offer to take tourists or researchers to see "domesticated" leopards in return for cash, but so far none of these "kept leopard chases" has been known to end in a successful sighting.<ref name=Swai1983/><ref name=Marshall>Marshall, S. (1994). ''The Status of the Zanzibar Leopard''. SIT Tanzania & Commission for Natural Resources, Zanzibar.</ref><ref name=Selkow>Selkow, B. (1995). ''A Survey of Villager Perceptions of the Zanzibar Leopard''. SIT Tanzania & Commission for Natural Resources, Zanzibar.</ref>
These conflicting perceptions of the Zanzibar leopard's status and the possibility of its conservation have yet to be reconciled, presenting a dilemma that has been highlighted by researchers.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Goldman, H.V. |author2=Walsh, M.T. |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 2007 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/13986864/HumanWildlife-Conflict-Unequal-Knowledge-and-the-Failure-to-Conserve-the-Zanzibar-Leopard-Panthera-pardus-adersi/ | title = Human-Wildlife Conflict, Unequal Knowledge and the Failure to Conserve the Zanzibar Leopard (''Panthera pardus adersi'') | work = Poster presented to the Felid Biology and Conservation Conference, Wildlife Conservation Research Unit (WildCRU), University of Oxford, 17–21 September 2007 | accessdate = 2009-07-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=Goldman, H.V. |author2=Walsh, M.T. |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 2008 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/13986833/When-Culture-Threatens-the-Conservation-of-Biological-Diversity-The-Tragic-Case-of-the-Zanzibar-Leopard-Panthera-pardus-adersi/ | title = When Culture Threatens the Conservation of Biological Diversity: The Tragic Case of the Zanzibar Leopard (''Panthera pardus adersi'') | work = Poster presented to Sustaining Cultural and Biological Diversity in a Rapidly Changing World: Lessons for Global Policy, Thirteenth Annual Symposium of the Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, American Museum of Natural History, New York, 2–5 April 2008 | accessdate = 2009-07-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Walsh | first1 = M.T. | last2 = Goldman | first2 = H.V. | year = 2012 | title = Chasing Imaginary Leopards: Science, Witchcraft and the Politics of Conservation in Zanzibar | journal = Journal of Eastern African Studies | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | pages = 727–746 | doi = 10.1080/17531055.2012.729778 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Walsh|first=M.T.|last2=Goldman|first2=H.V.|date=|year=2017|title=Cryptids and credulity: The Zanzibar leopard and other imaginary beings|url=https://www.taylorfrancis.com/books/e/9781317180463/chapters/10.4324/9781315567297-11|journal=Anthropology and Cryptozoology: Exploring Encounters with Mysterious Creatures|language=en|publisher=Routledge|publication-place=London|volume=|pages=54–90|doi=10.4324/9781315567297}}</ref>
==Possible survival== In 2018, a camera trap, placed for an [[Animal Planet]] show called ''Extinct or Alive'', caught apparent footage of a leopard on Unguja Island. The leopard appeared smaller than leopards from the mainland, and seemed to have smaller, more solid spots than normally seen on African leopards. Further investigations are planned in order to confirm whether or not this is a Zanzibar leopard, and whether a viable population still exists.<ref name=":0" />
